awd_titl_txt: Math Practice for Physics: Building Math Fluency in an Introductory Undergraduate Physics Context
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving math fluency in introductory physics courses. The goal is to use research-based principles, together with methods from cognitive psychology and education research,  to develop, implement, and assess a set of practice assignments called Math Practice. Math Practice is based on Essential Skills, an existing online platform used at Ohio State University. The initial scope of this project is to advance knowledge about how to address students' difficulties with math skills that are needed for success in introductory physics courses.  This initial work will involve the 15,000 students in introductory physics courses at the target schools. However, because this intervention is both low-cost and logistically simple to implement, it could potentially improve performance and retention of the 500,000 students enrolled each year in physics classes nationwide. Furthermore, although the Math Practice application will be designed to help all students, it is likely to especially help underprepared students succeed and continue in physics courses. 

The design of this proposed intervention is based on well-established research-based learning methods, including spaced and interleaved mastery practice with immediate feedback. This method is expected to automate and thereby reduce the cognitive load involved in applying basic math procedures in physics. Reducing cognitive load is important since physics tends to have complex, perceptually rich notation and contexts. The experimental design will include control conditions and "A/B testing" to explore optimal practice tasks and formats, such as comparison of alternative solutions and combinations of generic and context-rich format practice. The assessments will include validated math instruments, course performance, and motivational survey scales. These assessments will be used for iterative improvement of materials, investigation of areas of student difficulty, and investigation of potentially important student-level factors of performance and motivation. As a result, the practice tasks and assignment design will have a strong empirical and theoretical basis. Further, this project is expected to advance knowledge about student difficulties with essential math skills and the mechanisms underlying these difficulties, in an introductory physics context. In addition, it is expected to advance knowledge of the effectiveness of several specific kinds of empirically and theoretically promising math practice tasks. Finally, the project is expected to determine the extent to which student characteristics and  motivations interact with this intervention. Thus, it will potentially provide information about the mechanisms of the difficulties and additional avenues for productive interventions. Given that math is essential in all STEM disciplines, the information learned in this project could potentially extend to all of STEM education. For example, the difficulties students have with symbolic notation in introductory physics are also likely to be encountered in other areas of STEM. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed, tested, and refined a mathematics diagnostic test focused on pre-college mathematics, and we administered it to thousands of introductory college physics students at the beginning of their courses. Our objective was to investigate the students' level of mathematical preparation and to assess their specific difficulties with various mathematical topics. Our ultimate goal was to use this research to support the development of instructional materials and methods that might help students improve their performance in their physics courses. Our original diagnostic test was open (free) response in which students wrote out their solutions in detail; scoring and analysis of this test was extremely time-consuming. As part of this project we created a multiple-choice version of the test that can be administered on-line and is quick and easy to score, and we carefully fine-tuned this version so that it would give us nearly the same information as the free-response version administered on paper.  Students usually spend between 10-30 minutes responding to the test. We have begun to disseminate this test more widely to college science instructors.

During the course of this project we discovered that students who had high scores on our mathematics test, given during the first week or two of class, were much more likely to obtain high grades in the course, and much less likely to obtain low grades, than low scorers. We decided to extend our study by administering pre-instruction tests of both scientific reasoning ability (using the well-known Lawson test) and physics conceptual knowledge (using the Force Concept Inventory, an extensively tested and validated diagnostic tool). We confirmed that there was a significant relationship between students' final physics course grades and their pre-instruction performance on all three diagnostic tests: mathematics, reasoning, and physics concepts. High scorers on any of the three tests had a much higher probability of obtaining high course grades than did low scorers on the same test.

We found that which of the three pre-instruction diagnostic measures (math, scientific reasoning, and physics concepts) is the most efficient predictor of students' course grade varies greatly from course to course. We found that the class-average score on any of the single items on our math diagnostic was highly predictive of class-average scores on the full 16-item diagnostic. This implies that students' difficulties with different specific math skills are highly correlated with each other and thus potentially resistant to single-target remedial efforts. It also suggests that remediation efforts, in order to be effective, need to start well before students arrive in college.

We carried out more than a dozen one-on-one problem-solving interviews with students and through these confirmed our diagnostic test results regarding the widespread disregard and/or confusion many students have regarding use of physical units (such as m2 for area and m/s for velocity). Since physics courses all make heavy use of physical units, our findings suggest that intense and sustained practice with units may be needed for introductory physics students to attain the necessary degree of proficiency with them. We also confirmed a separate finding of ours that the use of symbols (such as Greek or Latin letters) instead of numbers, in problems involving algebraic equations, dramatically increases the difficulty of those problems for students in all types of introductory physics courses, both algebra-based and calculus-based.

The potential broader impacts of this project stem from our creation and testing of a convenient online tool to diagnose mathematics-related difficulties that can cause obstacles to success in college STEM courses. We created a knowledge base that may be used to assess and potentially address these obstacles, opening a window into possible means of early intervention to detect and aid students who might need special assistance in their physics courses. Our work suggests a need to increase and improve assessments in early education to ensure that background needed for college work is being acquired successfully. Similarly, it demonstrates a need for improvements in pre-college education (K-12) that are specifically targeted to support the education of students interested in STEM fields who are planning to go on to further studies in college.
